BHP Billiton Petroleum (Tx Gathering)
Hawkville Far East Early Production Site
Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

BHP Billiton Petroleum (Tx Gathering), LLC (BHPB) and Zephyr Gas Services (Zephyr) have a standing commitment to worker and public safety, demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention.  These resources include safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the process at the Hawkville Far East Early Production Site (Hawkville FE) and training of operations personnel and contractors.  BHPB and Zephyr implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  BHPB and Zephyr place emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspections and regularly training responsible personnel.  Should a release occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release, and prevent or mitigate any off-site consequences.

2. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Hawkville FE, located in McMullen County, Texas, is owned by BHPB and operated by Zephyr.  Hawkville FE is a natural gas processing plant comprised of natural gas liquid recovery, natural gas liquids fractionation, and natural gas treatment and compression equipment.  Produced gas and liquids are delivered to Hawkville FE from gathering systems and pipelines.  The natural gas liquid recovery equipment is designed to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas.  Hawkville FE produces natural gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate.  The Hawkville FE equipment operates to separate, stabilize, treat (as necessary to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide), compress (gas), dehydrate (gas), store (natural gas liquids and stabilized condensate), and transfer gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate to sales.  Natural gas is

transported by pipeline from Hawkville FE and natural gas liquids and stabilized condensate are transported by cargo tank motor vehicles.

The listed flammable substance above the threshold quantities at Hawkville FE is a flammable mixture containing methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane and pentane.  No toxic substances are present in the process.  Hawkville FE complies with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements and Program 1 requirements of the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program (RMP). 

3. General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

Implementation of appropriate administrative and technological safeguards in the process ensures the safety of workers and the surrounding community.  The Hawkville FE process has been designed using current equipment design codes and standards with appropriate safety controls.  The process design includes control systems to maintain operating parameters, such as temperature, pressures, flow, and level within allowable limits.  Written operating procedures for the process are developed, maintained, and periodically reviewed for safe operations.  Personnel operating the process are trained on the operating procedures to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable safety and operability limits and steps to correct deviation from normal operating parameters.  Additionally, BHPB and Zephyr have developed maintenance procedures to maintain equipment integrity.   

BHPB and Zephyr implemented safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety at Hawkville FE.  Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a

explosion and notification of local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release.  Employees are trained on the emergency procedures and the procedures are updated as needed when the process or facility is modified.  Changes to the emergency procedures are administered through the Management of Change process.

The overall emergency response program for Hawkville FE is coordinated with the McMullen County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Coordination includes periodic meetings to communicate Hawkville FE operations, contact information, and response activities.  BHPB has 24/7 communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., McMullen County LEPC Chairman, McMullen County Sheriff and Tilden Fire Department).  The LEPC would assist the Hawkville FE, as requested, to notify the public, control traffic, and facilitate response to an incident.  BHPB provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated flammable substances in Hawkville FE.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

All personnel, employees, and contractors are encouraged to notify their supervisor of any changes or modifications to Hawkville FE that could result in improved safety. BHPB and Zephyr track and resolves all process hazard analysis recommendations.  Plans to improve safety include evaluating the operation for any additional safety needs and considering installation of process area detection systems.

These procedures, along with training of involved personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.
	
Specific Prevention Steps

Hazards in the process at Hawkville FE are continually managed to ensure safe operations.  The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP covered process at Hawkville FE and covers all individually listed flammable substances and regulated flammable mixtures.  The prevention program is designed and implemented to prevent accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.  Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of Hawkville FE to help prevent, quickly detect, and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process: 

Release Containment and Control
Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and combust releases.
Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters. 
Containment areas to contain liquid releases.
Dual mechanical seals on hydrocarbon liquid pumps, where feasible. 
Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) system.

Release Mitigation
Portable fire extinguishers. 
Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
Personal protective equipment.

4. Five Year Accident History

BHPB has an excellent record of accident prevention.  Hawkville FE is a new facility and there is no accident history.
